channel.title: Repainting in an app
channel.description:
Okay, my latest problem, I cannot seem to call the repaint method on my app.
I want to use the [i]run()[/i] method to call repaint() every 50 millis.. it doesn't work. When I change it to call the paint(Graphics) method I use paint(this.getGraphics()) it does something and throws a NullPointerException.
How do I repaint?

item.dc:creator: @supamagier supamagier

@supamagier wrote:

You’re welcome. And yes, I think this should be locked

@pizza_pie wrote:

Well, I officially figured it out. Works well thanks to supamagier for the example. It was there when I noticed the I could only create the blank Image in the init() method when I tried to create it in the constructor of the class file it did not work. Well, thanks supamagier.

item.dc:creator: @supamagier supamagier
item.description:
@supamagier wrote:

[quote=“chrisn2323, post:30, topic:214298”]I usually override paintComponent(Graphics g) and first call super.paintComponent(g);

(That’s if you are using swing)[/quote]
That’s if you are making a GUI, paint(Graphics) is for Applets.

item.title: Repainting in an app
item.dc:creator: @supamagier supamagier
item.description:
@supamagier wrote:

Okay… I made something what might help you, it’s an applet, it repaints, via repaint() in run(), and it uses double buffering

import java.awt.*;
import java.applet.*;

public class Applet1 extends Applet implements Runnable
{
    Thread timer;           // The timer (Thread)
    Image offscreen;        // For double buffering
    Graphics b;             // For double buffering
    int X = 240;            // X Coordinate
    int Y = 140;            // Y Coordinate
    final int R = 20;       // Radius of the oval
    
    final int cycletime = 100;   // Sleep every 100 ms
    
	public void init() {

		setLayout(null);
		setSize(500,300);
		offscreen = createImage(getWidth(), getHeight());
		b = offscreen.getGraphics();
		timer = new Thread(this);
		timer.start();
	}
	
	public void paint(Graphics g) { 
	    b.clearRect(0,0,getWidth(),getHeight());
	    b.fillOval(X, Y, R, R);
	    g.drawImage(offscreen,0,0,this);
	    
	    X += (Math.random()*10 >= 5)?(Math.random()*30):(Math.random()*-30);
	    Y += (Math.random()*10 >= 5)?(Math.random()*30):(Math.random()*-30);
	    
	    if (X+R > getWidth())
	        X = getWidth()-R;
	    if (X < 0)
	        X = 0;
	    if (Y+R > getHeight())
	        Y = getHeight()-R;
	    if (Y < 0)
	        Y = 0;
	    
	}
	public void update(Graphics g) {
	    paint(g);
	}
	
	public void run() {
	    while (true) {
	        repaint();
	        try {
	            timer.sleep(cycletime);
	        }
	        catch (InterruptedException ie) {
	            System.out.println("Error in sleeping: "+ie); 
	            timer = null;
	        }
	    }
	}
}

It may help you, here you go.

Read full topic
